name: Create an ADI Service Account in Active Directory
title: Create an ADI Service Account in Active Directory
body:
To set up Active Directory Integration, you must use a Domain Admin account, or set up a new user in AD with the following permissions for the ADI Sync setup:

  • read all user information
  • read all inetOrgPerson information

Below are instructions showing how to create an AD User with necessary read permissions:

  1. Open Active Directory. Right-click on your domain and select Delegate Control.
  2. On the Delegation of Control Wizard, add your ADI Service account (created previously).
  3. Delegate the following Tasks:
    • Read all user information
    • Read all inetOrgPerson
  4. Finally, you will need to reconfigure your ADI sync service if you want to use your new AD service account with ADI.  
    • To change the specified user browse to the C:\ProgramData\KnowBe4\ADI Sync\Config folder and delete the file named <domain>.dat. Then, open an elevated CMD and browse to the C:\Program Files\KnowBe4\ADI Sync folder, and then type: "adisync.exe config".

This image displays the **Active Directory Users and Computers (ADUC)** Microsoft Management Console (MMC) snap-in, configured for the domain **DevKB4-a.com**.

**UI Context and Structure:**

*   **Application:** Active Directory Users and Computers, running in a classic Windows environment (likely Server OS).
*   **Menu/Toolbar:** Standard MMC menus (`File`, `Action`, `View`, `Help`) and a command toolbar are visible at the top.
*   **Scope Pane (Left):** This pane displays the domain tree hierarchy. The root domain, `DevKB4-a.com`, is selected. Numerous Organizational Units (OUs) and default containers are listed, including expanded nodes for `Dev Users` (showing `Actors`, `Development`, `Singers, Songwriters`, and `Various_Heros`), `Domain Controllers`, `Users`, and others.
*   **Results Pane (Right):** Lists the objects within the selected `DevKB4-a.com` domain, showing columns for `Name`, `Type`, and `Description`. The listed objects are `DevKB4-a.com` and `Saved Queries`.

**Active Interaction:**

*   **Context Menu:** A context menu (right-click menu) is displayed over the Results Pane, indicating that the user has right-clicked the selected domain object (`DevKB4-a.com`).
*   **Selected Option:** The first item, **"Delegate Control..."**, is highlighted, indicating the action the user is currently targeting.
*   **Menu Options Visible:** The menu provides key domain management options:
    *   `Delegate Control...`
    *   `Find...`
    *   `Change Domain...`
    *   `Change Domain Controller...`
    *   `Raise domain functional level...`
    *   `Operations Masters...`
    *   Separators are present before and after a section containing `New` and `All Tasks` (both with sub-menu arrows), followed by `Refresh`, `Properties`, and `Help`.
*   **Status Bar:** The status bar at the bottom confirms the action associated with the highlighted menu item: "Delegates control of objects in this folder".

The image displays a step within the **Delegation of Control Wizard**, titled **Users or Groups**.

**Context and Instruction:**
The main instructional text reads: "Select one or more users or groups to whom you want to delegate control." An icon representing two keys (security/access) is present in the upper right corner.

**UI Elements:**
*   A section labeled **"Selected users and groups:"** contains a large, empty list box designed to display delegated entities.
*   Two control buttons are positioned adjacent to the list box:
    *   **Add...** (Active)
    *   **Remove** (Disabled/Greyed out, as the list is empty)

**Navigation Controls (Footer):**
The footer contains standard wizard navigation:
*   **< Back** (Active)
*   **Next >** (Disabled/Greyed out)
*   **Cancel** (Active)
*   **Help** (Active)
images.context: On the Delegation of Control Wizard, add your ADI Service account (created previously).

images.alt:
The image displays the "Tasks to Delegate" step within the "Delegation of Control Wizard." The screen presents two radio button options for defining the delegation scope.

The radio button **"Delegate the following common tasks"** is selected, presenting a scrollable list box of common permissions using checkboxes. The permission **"Read all user information"** is currently checked. Other visible, unselected common tasks include: "Create, delete, and manage user accounts," "Reset user passwords and force password change at next logon," "Create, delete and manage groups," "Modify the membership of a group," "Manage Group Policy links," and "Generate Resultant Set of Policy (Planning)."

The second, unselected radio button option is **"Create a custom task to delegate."**

Standard wizard navigation buttons are present at the bottom of the dialogue box: **< Back**, **Next >**, **Cancel**, and **Help**.
